profitMakingTips.title: Nafa Milvanyache Tips
profitMakingTips.description: Aaplya shetichi nafashilta vadhvinyasathi yuktya shodha.
profitMakingTips.pageSubtitle: तुमचे कृषी उत्पन्न वाढवण्यासाठी आणि टिकाऊपणा सुनिश्चित करण्यासाठी स्मार्ट रणनीती.
profitMakingTips.tip1_desc: सेंद्रिय भाज्या, हळद, मशरूम किंवा औषधी वनस्पतींसारख्या सातत्यपूर्ण बाजार मागणी असलेल्या पिकांवर लक्ष केंद्रित करा. यांना अनेकदा प्रीमियम भाव मिळतात आणि त्यांची चक्रे लहान असतात.
profitMakingTips.tip2_desc: विविध हंगामांमध्ये पीक कामगिरीची तुलना करण्यासाठी डेटा वापरा. यामुळे तुम्हाला कोणते पीक गुंतवणुकीवर सर्वोत्तम परतावा देते आणि कुठे इनपुट ऑप्टिमाइझ करायचे हे ओळखण्यास मदत होते.
profitMakingTips.tip3_desc: ठिबक सिंचन, पावसाच्या पाण्याची साठवण आणि मातीतील ओलावा सेन्सर पाण्याच्या अपव्ययात मोठी घट करू शकतात आणि पीक आरोग्य सुधारू शकतात—विशेषतः पाणी-टंचाई असलेल्या प्रदेशात.
profitMakingTips.tip4_desc: माती परीक्षण तुम्हाला योग्य प्रमाणात योग्य खत वापरण्यास मदत करते. ते अतिवापर टाळते, पैसे वाचवते आणि उत्पन्न वाढवते. तुम्ही तुमच्या अॅपच्या फॉर्म फ्लोमध्येही हा तर्क समाकलित करू शकता.
profitMakingTips.tip5_desc: तुमच्या शेतात मधमाशी पालन, दुग्धव्यवसाय किंवा पोल्ट्री जोडा. हे स्थिर उत्पन्न देतात आणि पीक चक्रांना पूरक ठरतात. बोनस: मधमाश्या परागण आणि उत्पन्न सुधारतात.
profitMakingTips.tip6_desc: खत, हवामान आणि माती डेटावर आधारित पीक परिणामांचे अनुकरण करण्यासाठी Genkit AI किंवा तत्सम मॉडेलचा लाभ घ्या. हे नियोजन आणि जोखीम कमी करण्यास मदत करते.
profitMakingTips.tip7_desc: कच्चा माल विकण्याऐवजी, त्यावर प्रक्रिया करा—जसे टोमॅटोचे प्युरी किंवा हळदीचे पावडर बनवणे. मूल्यवर्धित उत्पादने जास्त दराने विकली जातात आणि जास्त काळ टिकतात.
profitMakingTips.tip8_desc: मध्यस्थांना टाळण्यासाठी व्हॉट्सअॅप कॅटलॉग, स्थानिक शेतकरी बाजार किंवा अगदी साधे वेब अॅप वापरा. थेट विक्री = चांगले मार्जिन आणि ग्राहक अभिप्राय.
profitMakingTips.tip9_desc: पीक फेरपालट मातीचे आरोग्य सुधारते आणि कीटकांचा प्रादुर्भाव कमी करते. नायट्रोजनची पातळी नैसर्गिकरित्या संतुलित करण्यासाठी डाळींबरोबर तृणधान्ये किंवा तेलबिया लावा.
profitMakingTips.tip10_desc: खर्च, उत्पन्न, हवामान आणि बाजारभाव डिजिटल पद्धतीने ट्रॅक करा. हे ऑडिट, सबसिडी अर्ज आणि हुशार निर्णय घेण्यास मदत करते.

croppingPatterns.title: Cropping Patterns
croppingPatterns.description: Understand how cropping patterns vary across India and what factors influence them.

cropsKnowledge.title: Crops Knowledge
cropsKnowledge.description: Detailed information about major crops grown in India, their requirements, and ideal conditions.
cropsKnowledge.pageSubtitle: A comprehensive guide to India's major agricultural crops.

rice.title: Rice
rice.states: West Bengal > Punjab > Uttar Pradesh > Andhra Pradesh > Bihar.
rice.notes: Staple food for the majority. India is the 2nd largest producer. Three crops (Aus, Aman, Boro) are grown in some states.

wheat.title: Wheat
wheat.soil: Well-drained fertile loamy and clayey loamy soils.
wheat.states: Uttar Pradesh > Punjab > Madhya Pradesh > Haryana > Rajasthan.
wheat.notes: Second most important cereal crop, main food in North India. Green Revolution greatly boosted its growth.

millets.title: Millets (Nutri-Cereals)
millets.soil: Can be grown in inferior alluvial or loamy soil.
millets.states: Rajasthan > Karnataka > Maharashtra > Madhya Pradesh > Uttar Pradesh
millets.notes: Also known as coarse grains, high nutritional value. Ragi is rich in iron and calcium.

maize.title: Maize
maize.states: Karnataka > Maharashtra > Madhya Pradesh > Tamil Nadu > Telangana
maize.notes: India is the 7th largest producer. Used as both food and fodder. Production increased with HYV seeds.

pulses.title: Pulses
pulses.states: Madhya Pradesh > Rajasthan > Maharashtra > Uttar Pradesh > Karnataka.
pulses.notes: India is the largest producer and consumer. Major source of protein. Leguminous crops restore soil fertility.

sugarcane.title: Sugarcane
sugarcane.temp: Between 21-27°C with hot and humid climate.
sugarcane.states: Uttar Pradesh > Maharashtra > Karnataka > Tamil Nadu > Bihar.
sugarcane.notes: India is the 2nd largest producer after Brazil. Main source of sugar, jaggery, and molasses.

oilseeds.title: Oilseeds
oilseeds.soil: Loam to clayey loam and well drained sandy loams.
oilseeds.states: Madhya Pradesh > Rajasthan > Gujarat > Maharashtra > Uttar Pradesh.
oilseeds.notes: Includes groundnut, mustard, soyabean, etc. Most are edible; some used for soaps and cosmetics.

cropsKnowledge.horticulture_desc: India is the second largest producer of fruits and vegetables. It produces about 13 percent of the world’s vegetables.
cropsKnowledge.mangoes_states: Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal
cropsKnowledge.bananas_states: Kerala, Mizoram, Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu
cropsKnowledge.apples_states: Jammu and Kashmir and Himachal Pradesh

tea.title: Tea
tea.soil: Deep and fertile well-drained soil, rich in humus.
tea.notes: India is the 2nd largest producer. It is a labor-intensive industry requiring skilled labor.

coffee.title: Coffee
coffee.soil: Well drained, deep friable loamy soil.
coffee.notes: India is the 7th largest producer. The 'Arabica' variety from India is famous worldwide.

rubber.title: Rubber
rubber.temp: Above 25°C with moist and humid climate.
rubber.notes: It is an equatorial crop but can be grown in tropical and sub-tropical areas. It's an important industrial raw material.

cotton.title: Cotton
cotton.soil: Well drained black cotton soil of Deccan Plateau.
cotton.states: Gujarat > Maharashtra > Telangana > Andhra Pradesh > Rajasthan.
cotton.notes: Requires 210 frost-free days and bright sunshine. BT Cotton is a genetically modified variety.

jute.title: Jute
jute.states: West Bengal > Bihar > Assam > Andhra Pradesh > Odisha.
jute.notes: Known as the golden fibre. Used in making bags, ropes, etc. Losing market to synthetic fibres.

cropsKnowledge.changing_p1: Cropping pattern is a dynamic concept, referring to the proportion of area under various crops at a point in time, and the sequence and spatial arrangement of crops.
cropsKnowledge.changing_l1: The Green Revolution led to changes, introducing rice to Punjab and Haryana.
cropsKnowledge.changing_l2: New technologies have made food crop cultivation more productive.
cropsKnowledge.changing_l3: There's a shift towards cash crops like oilseeds, fruits, and vegetables.
cropsKnowledge.changing_l4: Factors like climate change, economic expansion, and urbanization continue to influence these patterns.

quotes.q1: Sheti fakt ek kam nahi, ti ek jivan shaili aahe.
quotes.q2: Shetkari aaplya arthavyavasthetil ekmev manus aahe jo sarva kahi retail madhye kharedi karto, sarva kahi wholesale madhye vikto, aani donhi bajunche bhade deto.
quotes.q3: Shetkaryanshivay, ann nahi. Annashivay, jivan nahi.
quotes.q4: To forget how to dig the earth and tend the soil is to forget ourselves.
quotes.q5: Farming is the art of patience, the science of soil, and the soul of survival.
quotes.q6: The ultimate goal of farming is not the growing of crops, but the cultivation of humans.
quotes.q7: Agriculture is the backbone of the nation.
quotes.q8: Farmers feed the world, yet they often eat last.
quotes.q9: When tillage begins, other arts follow. The farmers are the founders of human civilization.
quotes.q10: Soil is the great connector of lives, the source and destination of all.
quotes.q11: A farmer’s hands may be rough, but they grow the world’s softest bread.
quotes.q12: Farming is the profession of hope.
quotes.q13: Healthy soil, healthy food, healthy people.
quotes.q14: The best fertilizer for the land is the farmer’s footsteps.
quotes.q15: A society that forgets its farmers is a society without a future.
quotes.q16: Farming is the only business where you truly work with nature, not against it.
quotes.q17: The miracle of agriculture is turning a seed into a thousand meals.
quotes.q18: Farmers plant hope for the future in every seed.
quotes.q19: Good farmers take care of the soil, and the soil takes care of them.
quotes.q20: Farming is the greatest service to humanity.
quotes.q21: The future belongs to those who feed it.
quotes.q22: Rain or shine, farmers keep the world alive.
quotes.q23: Farmers don’t just grow crops, they grow nations.
quotes.q24: Every farmer is a scientist, experimenting with the earth.
quotes.q25: Respect the hands that feed you.
quotes.q26: A good farmer is nothing less than a hero.
quotes.q27: The land is more than soil; it is history, roots, and identity.
quotes.q28: In every seed lies a story of tomorrow.
quotes.q29: Farming is both tradition and innovation.
quotes.q30: A farmer’s sweat is sweeter than gold, because it grows life.
quotes.q31: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field!
quotes.q32: Why don’t farmers ever get lost? Because they always follow the tractor’s GPS… “Ground Positioning System.”
quotes.q33: Why did the cow go to space? To see the “milky way!”
quotes.q34: What did the farmer say after he lost his tractor? “Where’s my tractor?”
quotes.q35: Why did the tomato blush? Because it saw the farmer dressing his salad!
quotes.q36: Why did the farmer bring a pencil to the field? To draw his crops.
quotes.q37: What’s a farmer’s favorite type of music? “Crop” music.
quotes.q38: Why are farmers so good at math? Because they’re used to “multiplying” crops.
quotes.q39: Why was the farmer always calm? Because he knew how to “keep his peas.”
quotes.q40: What do farmers use to make crop circles? A pro-tractor!
quotes.q41: Why did the cow sit under the tree? Because it wanted some “moo-d” shade.
quotes.q42: Why do potatoes make good detectives? Because they keep their “eyes” open.
quotes.q43: What’s a farmer’s favorite type of joke? Corny ones. 🌽
quotes.q44: Why did the tractor blush? Because it saw the farmer plow-ing.
quotes.q45: Why don’t chickens ever tell secrets? Because they might “egg-spose” them.
quotes.q46: Why did the farmer plant a seed in his computer? To grow a website!
quotes.q47: Why are farmers good comedians? Because they have “field experience.”
quotes.q48: What did the farmer say when his crops were singing? “Sounds like a good harvest tune.”
quotes.q49: Why did the farmer start using AI? Because his crops needed a little “byte” of help.
quotes.q50: Why do cows wear bells? Because their horns don’t work!
quotes.q51: Without farmers, there is no food security.
quotes.q52: Every time you waste food, remember a farmer’s sweat went into it.
quotes.q53: Save water today, so crops can grow tomorrow.
quotes.q54: Support local farmers — they feed your community.
quotes.q55: Sustainable farming is the future of food.
quotes.q56: Healthy soil, healthy food, healthy people.
quotes.q57: Climate change affects farmers first — act now.
quotes.q58: Fair price for farmers means fair food for all.
quotes.q59: Farmers don’t need sympathy, they need support.
quotes.q61: Use organic methods, protect future generations.
quotes.q62: Technology in farming can double food security.
quotes.q63: Protect the farmer, protect the nation.
quotes.q64: Farming is not just work, it’s service to humanity.
quotes.q65: A hungry farmer cannot feed a hungry nation.
quotes.q66: Agriculture is not an industry, it’s a lifeline.
quotes.q67: Invest in farmers, and you invest in the nation’s future.
quotes.q69: Don’t take your plate for granted — thank a farmer.

news.n1_title: New Drone Technology Revolutionizes Crop Monitoring
news.n1_snippet: Advanced drones equipped with multispectral sensors are providing farmers with unprecedented insights into crop health, enabling early detection of stress and disease.
news.n1_article: Advanced drones equipped with multispectral sensors are providing farmers with unprecedented insights into crop health, enabling early detection of stress and disease. This technology allows for targeted intervention, reducing the need for broad-spectrum pesticides and optimizing resource use. The result is higher yields, lower costs, and a more sustainable approach to farming.
news.n2_title: Government Announces Increased Subsidies for Organic Farming
news.n2_snippet: In a move to promote sustainable agriculture, the government has rolled out a new package of subsidies aimed at farmers transitioning to or practicing organic farming methods.
news.n2_article: In a move to promote sustainable agriculture, the government has rolled out a new package of subsidies aimed at farmers transitioning to or practicing organic farming methods. The package includes financial incentives for certification, market access support, and training programs on organic practices. This initiative is expected to significantly boost the organic sector in the coming years.
news.n3_title: Weather Patterns Shift: Farmers Adapt to a Changing Climate
news.n3_snippet: A new report highlights the innovative strategies farmers are adopting to cope with unpredictable weather, from drought-resistant crops to advanced irrigation systems.
news.n3_article: A new report highlights the innovative strategies farmers are adopting to cope with unpredictable weather, from drought-resistant crops to advanced irrigation systems. The report emphasizes the importance of climate-resilient agriculture and showcases case studies of successful adaptation from around the world, offering valuable lessons for farmers everywhere.
news.n4_title: Corn Prices Surge Amidst Global Supply Concerns
news.n4_snippet: Analysts report a significant increase in corn futures as poor weather conditions in major producing regions threaten the global supply chain.
news.n4_article: Analysts report a significant increase in corn futures as poor weather conditions in major producing regions threaten the global supply chain. The surge is putting pressure on livestock feed prices and raising concerns about food inflation. Experts are closely monitoring the situation as the harvest season progresses.
news.n5_title: The Rise of No-Till Farming: A Guide for Beginners
news.n5_snippet: No-till farming is gaining popularity for its benefits to soil health and water conservation. This guide breaks down how to get started.
news.n5_article: No-till farming is gaining popularity for its benefits to soil health and water conservation. This guide breaks down how to get started, covering topics such as equipment needs, cover cropping strategies, and potential challenges. By minimizing soil disturbance, farmers can enhance biodiversity and reduce erosion.
news.n6_title: New AI-Powered App Helps Farmers Identify Pests Instantly
news.n6_snippet: A startup has launched a mobile app that uses artificial intelligence to identify crop pests from a single photo, offering instant treatment recommendations.
news.n6_article: A startup has launched a mobile app that uses artificial intelligence to identify crop pests from a single photo, offering instant treatment recommendations. The app, which has a database of thousands of pests, aims to democratize access to expert agronomic advice and help farmers make timely decisions to protect their crops.
news.n7_snippet: The Pradhan Mantri Kisan Maandhan Yojana (PM-KMY) is a voluntary and contributory pension scheme launched by the Government of India on 12 September 2019. The scheme is specially designed for small and marginal farmers to ensure financial security in their old age.
news.n7_article:
The Pradhan Mantri Kisan Maandhan Yojana (PM-KMY) is a voluntary and contributory pension scheme launched by the Government of India on 12 September 2019. The scheme is specially designed for small and marginal farmers to ensure financial security in their old age.

It was introduced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi with the vision of providing farmers a dignified life after retirement.

Objective of PM-KMY

  • To provide financial assistance to small and marginal farmers after 60 years of age.
  • To ensure that farmers do not remain dependent on others for their daily needs in old age.
  • To give a guaranteed monthly pension of ₹3,000 for a secure future.

Eligibility

  • Small and marginal farmers with cultivable land up to 2 hectares.
  • Age between 18 and 40 years at the time of joining.

Not Eligible:

  • Farmers covered under NPS, EPF, or ESIC.
  • Institutional landholders and big landlords.
  • Present or former constitutional post holders, ministers, MLAs/MPs.
  • Government employees (except Class IV/Group D staff).
  • Income tax payers in the last financial year.
  • Professionals such as doctors, engineers, lawyers, CAs, architects, etc.

    • Contribution Details

    Farmers need to contribute a small fixed amount (₹55 to ₹200 per month) depending on their entry age.

    • The government matches the farmer’s contribution on a 1:1 basis.
    • Contributions continue until the farmer reaches 60 years of age.
    • After 60 years, the farmer receives ₹3,000 monthly pension for life.

    How to Apply

    1. Visit the nearest Common Service Centre (CSC).
    2. Carry documents: Aadhaar Card, Bank Passbook, Land documents, and Passport size photo.
    3. Fill the enrollment form with details like name, spouse/nominee, Aadhaar, bank details, and mobile number.
    4. Provide auto-debit mandate so the contribution is deducted automatically.
    5. After verification, the farmer is issued a Unique Pension Account Number.

    Contribution Chart

    Entry Age (Years)Retirement AgeFarmer’s Contribution (₹/month)Government’s Contribution (₹/month)Total Contribution (₹/month)
    18605555110
    19605858116
    20606161122
    21606464128
    22606868136
    23607272144
    24607676152
    25608080160
    26608585170
    27609090180
    28609595190
    2960100100200
    3060105105210
    3160110110220
    3260120120240
    3360130130260
    3460140140280
    3560150150300
    3660160160320
    3760170170340
    3860180180360
    3960190190380
    4060200200400

    Special Rule for PM-Kisan Beneficiaries

    Farmers who are already receiving ₹6,000 per year under PM-Kisan Samman Nidhi can authorize the government to directly deduct the pension contribution from that amount. This makes it easier for them to join PM-KMY without extra burden.

    FAQs

    1. Is there any enrollment fee?

    A nominal fee of ₹30 is charged at CSCs, which is paid by the government.

    2. What if the farmer dies before 60 years?

    • The spouse can continue the scheme by contributing further.
    • If not, the total contribution made by the farmer (with interest) will be returned to the nominee.

    3. What if the farmer dies after 60 years?

    • The spouse will receive 50% of the pension as family pension (if not already a PM-KMY member).

    4. What if contributions are not paid on time?

    • Auto-debit happens on 1st, 11th, or 21st of the month.
    • If missed, contributions can be paid later with interest.
    • Accounts inactive for more than 3 years may be closed.

    Key Benefits of PM-KMY

    • ✅ Guaranteed ₹3,000 monthly pension after 60 years
    • ✅ Equal contribution by Government
    • ✅ Financial security in old age
    • ✅ Family pension to spouse in case of death
    • ✅ Simple enrollment through CSCs

    ✨ The Pradhan Mantri Kisan Maandhan Yojana is a strong step towards securing the future of India’s small and marginal farmers, ensuring dignity, stability, and financial independence in their later years.
news.n8_snippet: IMD ने पंजाबसाठी रेड अलर्ट जारी केला असून, पुढील ४८ तासांत अतिवृष्टीचा इशारा दिला आहे. ३ सप्टेंबरपर्यंत शाळा बंद.
news.n8_article: भारतीय हवामानशास्त्र विभागाने (IMD) रविवारी पंजाबसाठी रेड अलर्ट जारी केला आहे, ज्यात पुढील ४८ तासांत खूप जास्त ते अत्यंत जास्त पावसाची शक्यता वर्तवली आहे. हा प्रदेश आधीच सततच्या पावसाने आणि पूरसदृश परिस्थितीने त्रस्त आहे. हवामान अधिकाऱ्यांच्या म्हणण्यानुसार, या तीव्र पावसामुळे डोंगराळ पाणलोट क्षेत्रात पूर आणि भूस्खलन होण्याची शक्यता आहे, ज्यामुळे सखल शहरी भागात गंभीर पाणी साचू शकते. पावसाच्या प्रमाणामुळे आणि शक्तीमुळे कमकुवत किंवा असुरक्षित संरचनांचे नुकसान होऊ शकते, असा इशाराही विभागाने दिला आहे।
news.n9_title: पंजाबमध्ये ऑगस्टमध्ये ७४% अतिरिक्त पाऊस, २५ वर्षांतील सर्वाधिक
news.n9_snippet: पूरग्रस्त पंजाबमध्ये ऑगस्टमध्ये २५৩.৭ मिमी पाऊस झाला, जो केवळ सामान्यपेक्षा ७४% जास्त नव्हता, तर गेल्या ২৫ वर्षांत राज्याने पाहिलेला सर्वाधिक पाऊस होता.
news.n9_article: पूरग्रस्त पंजाबमध्ये ऑगस्टमध्ये २५৩.৭ मिमी पाऊस झाला, जो केवळ सामान्यपेक्षा ७४% जास्त नव्हता, तर गेल्या ২৫ वर्षांत राज्याने पाहिलेला सर्वाधिक पाऊस होता, असे अधिकाऱ्यांनी रविवारी (३१ ऑगस्ट, २०२५) सांगितले. शेजारील हरियाणामध्ये ऑगस्टमध्ये १९৪.৫ मिमी पाऊस झाला, जो महिन्याच्या सरासरी १४৭.৭ मिमीच्या तुलनेत ३२% वाढ दर्शवतो.
news.n10_snippet: रविवार ते मंगळवार या काळात हिमाचल प्रदेशातील चार ते सहा जिल्ह्यांमध्ये खूप जास्त ते अत्यंत जास्त पावसासाठी रेड अलर्ट जारी करण्यात आला आहे, भूस्खलन आणि अचानक पुराचा इशारा.
news.n10_article: हवामान केंद्राने रविवार (३१ ऑगस्ट, २०२۵) ते मंगळवार (२ सप्टेंबर, २०२۵) पर्यंत हिमाचल प्रदेशातील चार ते सहा जिल्ह्यांमध्ये खूप जास्त ते अत्यंत जास्त पावसासाठी रेड अलर्ट जारी केला आहे आणि भूस्ਖलन, अचानक पूर, जमीन खचणे, पाणी साचणे आणि जलसाठे फुगण्याचा इशारा दिला आहे।
news.n11_title: नैसर्गिक आपत्तीमुळे झालेल्या नुकसानीचे मूल्यांकन करण्यासाठी MHA ने केंद्रीय पथके स्थापन केली
news.n11_snippet: गृह मंत्रालयाने (MHA) अभूतपूर्व पाऊस आणि पुरामुळे प्रभावित राज्यांमध्ये नुकसानीचे मूल्यांकन करण्यासाठी आंतर-मंत्रालयीन केंद्रीय पथके (IMCTs) स्थापन केली आहेत.
news.n11_article: गृह मंत्रालयाने (MHA) गेल्या काही दिवसांपासून अभूतपूर्व पाऊस, पूर आणि इतर आपत्तींमुळे प्रभावित झालेल्या राज्यांमध्ये नुकसानीचे मूल्यांकन करण्यासाठी आंतर-मंत्रालयीन केंद्रीय पथके (IMCTs) स्थापन केली आहेत. हिमाचल प्रदेश, उत्तराखंड, पंजाब आणि जम्मू आणि काश्मीर केंद्रशासित प्रदेशासाठी प्रत्येकी एक IMCT स्थापन करण्यात आली आहे.
news.n12_title: पंजाब पुरात १,००० हून अधिक गावे प्रभावित
news.n12_snippet: पंजाबमधील पुरात १,००০ हून अधिक गावे आणि ६१,००০ हेक्टरपेक्षा जास्त शेतजमीन बाधित झाली आहे, मदत आणि बचाव कार्याला वेग आला आहे.
news.n12_article: पंजाबमधील पुरात गुरदासपूर जिल्ह्यात सर्वाधिक १,००০ हून अधिक गावे आणि ६१,००০ हेक्टरपेक्षा जास्त शेतजमीन बाधित झाली आहे, तर मदत आणि बचाव कार्याला वेग आला आहे. 'आप' सरकारच्या 'अकार्यक्षमते'मुळे पंजाबचे लोक त्रस्त आहेत, असा आरोप विरोधी पक्षांनी केला आहे.
news.n13_snippet: A look into subsistence farming, a type of agriculture where farmers grow crops for their own family's consumption.
news.n13_article:
Subsistence Farming in India

Definition:

Subsistence farming is a type of agriculture where farmers primarily grow crops and raise livestock for their own family’s consumption rather than for sale in the market. It is the backbone of rural India, especially among smallholder and marginal farmers.

Key Features

Small Landholdings:

  • Most subsistence farmers own less than 2 hectares of land.
  • Land is often fragmented, reducing efficiency.

Crops Grown:

  • Staples like rice, wheat, maize, millets, and pulses.
  • Sometimes vegetables and fruits for home use.
  • Cash crops are rare, as the focus is on household food security.

Farming Practices:

  • Heavy reliance on traditional tools (ploughs, bullocks) and manual labor.
  • Use of organic manure instead of chemical fertilizers in many areas.
  • Rain-fed agriculture dominates, as irrigation facilities are limited.

Livelihood Dependence:

  • Families often keep cows, goats, or poultry for milk, meat, and eggs.
  • Surplus, if any, is sold in local markets for minimal income.

Regional Concentration:

Common in states like Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Odisha, Jharkhand, West Bengal, and the North-Eastern states.

Advantages

  • Provides food security for rural households.
  • Preserves traditional seeds and organic practices.
  • Less dependence on external inputs reduces cash expenditure.

Challenges

  • Low Productivity: Yields are far below commercial farming due to small plots and low use of technology.
  • Weather Dependence: Heavy reliance on the monsoon makes farmers highly vulnerable to droughts and floods.
  • Market Exclusion: Minimal surplus means farmers cannot benefit much from agricultural markets or government schemes.
  • Poverty Cycle: Limited income keeps families trapped in subsistence, with little chance of moving to commercial farming.
  • Fragmentation of Land: Continuous division of land across generations reduces the viability of farming.

Recent Trends

  • Government Schemes: Initiatives like PM-KISAN, PMFBY (crop insurance), and irrigation programs aim to support small farmers.
  • Shift Toward Commercial Crops: In some regions, subsistence farmers are slowly moving towards vegetables or cash crops to earn additional income.
  • Technology Integration: NGOs and startups are introducing mobile apps, AI-based advisories, and better seed varieties to improve productivity.
news.n14_snippet: Understanding extensive farming, an agricultural system on large land with low inputs.
news.n14_article:
Extensive Farming

Definition:

Extensive farming is an agricultural system practiced on large stretches of land with low inputs of labor, capital, and technology compared to the size of the farm. The focus is on using land area rather than maximizing productivity per unit of land.

Key Features

Large Land Area:

  • Practiced over wide territories, often in regions where land is available at low cost.
  • Farms may stretch across hundreds or thousands of hectares.

Low Input Use:

  • Minimal use of labor, fertilizers, irrigation, or machinery.
  • Dependence on natural soil fertility and rainfall.

Crop Spacing:

  • Crops are widely spaced, allowing natural soil nutrients to sustain them.
  • Common crops: wheat, maize, barley, and oilseeds.

Mechanization:

  • Traditionally, mechanization is low, but in modern times, tractors and harvesters are sometimes used (especially in developed countries).

Geographical Spread:

Found in arid and semi-arid areas where water is scarce. More common in countries with large land availability like USA, Canada, Russia, and Australia. In India, it is seen in parts of Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, and Deccan Plateau where rainfall is low and land is relatively large but less fertile.

Advantages

  • Requires less investment in fertilizers, irrigation, and labor.
  • Suitable for regions where population density is low but land availability is high.
  • Less intensive farming reduces soil exhaustion compared to continuous intensive farming.

Challenges / Disadvantages

  • Low Productivity: Output per unit area is very low compared to intensive farming.
  • Soil Erosion & Degradation: Improper land management can lead to wind and water erosion.
  • Dependence on Climate: Success largely depends on rainfall patterns and natural fertility.
  • Economic Limitation: Since the yield is low, farmers may not get high profits unless the farm size is very large.

Recent Trends

  • Sustainable Practices: Introduction of drip irrigation, soil conservation, and drought-resistant crop varieties to reduce risks.
  • Mechanization in Developed Nations: Use of large-scale machinery in countries like the USA and Australia has made extensive farming more efficient.
  • Climate Change Concerns: Erratic rainfall and desertification make this system increasingly vulnerable.
news.n15_snippet: Plantation farming is a form of commercial agriculture with a focus on cash crops for export.
news.n15_article:
Plantation Farming

Definition:

Plantation farming is a form of commercial agriculture in which cash crops are grown intensively on large estates or plantations. The crops are mainly cultivated for export and industrial use, rather than local consumption.

Key Features

Cash Crop Focus:

  • Major crops: Tea, coffee, rubber, sugarcane, cotton, oil palm, spices, and cashew nuts.
  • The produce is often processed locally before being exported.

Large Estates:

  • Plantations usually cover large areas (hundreds to thousands of hectares).
  • Ownership is often corporate, though smallholder plantations also exist.

Monoculture System:

  • A single crop is grown extensively for commercial purposes.
  • This ensures economies of scale but also increases ecological risks.

Labor Intensive:

  • Plantation farming requires a large, often hired workforce for planting, maintenance, and harvesting.
  • Historically, plantations in India were linked with colonial systems of indentured and cheap labor.

Climatic Requirement:

  • Crops demand specific climatic conditions:
  • Tea & Coffee: Humid tropical and subtropical climates (Assam, Kerala, Karnataka).
  • Rubber: Hot, humid climate with heavy rainfall (Kerala, Tamil Nadu).
  • Spices: Moderate to tropical climates (Kerala, Karnataka, North-East India).

Advantages

  • Generates high revenue and contributes to foreign exchange through exports.
  • Provides employment opportunities for rural populations.
  • Encourages industrial growth, as plantation crops are raw materials for many industries (tea, textiles, sugar, etc.).

Disadvantages / Challenges

  • Deforestation & Environmental Impact: Large tracts of forests are cleared to set up plantations → leads to loss of biodiversity, soil erosion, and carbon emissions.
  • Monoculture Risks: Continuous monoculture makes crops vulnerable to pests, diseases, and climate change.
  • Labor Exploitation: Plantation workers often face low wages, poor working conditions, and seasonal unemployment.
  • Unequal Land Ownership: Plantations are controlled by a few large landowners or corporations, limiting benefits to small farmers.

Plantation Farming in India – Major Regions

  • Tea: Assam, West Bengal (Darjeeling), Kerala, Tamil Nadu.
  • Coffee: Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu.
  • Rubber: Kerala, Tamil Nadu, North-East states.
  • Spices: Kerala, Karnataka, North-East India.
  • Sugarcane & Cotton: Uttar Pradesh, Maharashtra, Gujarat, Punjab, Andhra Pradesh.

Recent Trends

  • Organic & Sustainable Plantations: Growing shift toward eco-friendly methods due to global demand.
  • Agroforestry Practices: Combining trees with plantations to reduce deforestation.
  • Technology Adoption: Use of drones, sensors, and AI in large plantations for monitoring and precision farming.
  • Certification & Exports: Fair Trade, Rainforest Alliance, and Organic certifications are boosting export value.
news.n16_snippet: Commercial farming is a market-oriented system using modern tech to maximize profit.
news.n16_article:
Commercial Farming

Definition:

Commercial farming is a type of agriculture where crops are grown primarily for trade, sale, and profit, rather than for subsistence. It is often market-oriented and uses modern technologies to maximize output and income.

Key Features

Profit-Oriented:

  • Main goal is to earn revenue through large-scale production.
  • Crops are often grown based on domestic and international market demand.

Use of Technology:

  • Adoption of high-yielding varieties (HYVs) of seeds.
  • Chemical fertilizers and pesticides are commonly used to boost productivity.
  • Advanced irrigation systems (drip irrigation, sprinklers, tube wells) to reduce water dependence.

Mechanization:

  • Use of tractors, harvesters, threshers, and drones for large-scale efficiency.

Market-Driven Crop Selection:

  • Crops: Rice, wheat, maize, sugarcane, cotton, tobacco, oilseeds, and horticultural crops.
  • Export-oriented crops like spices, tea, coffee, and flowers are also included.

Regional Practices:

Common in agriculturally advanced states like Punjab, Haryana, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, and Andhra Pradesh, where irrigation and mechanization are well established.

Advantages

  • Higher Productivity: Ensures greater crop output compared to traditional methods.
  • Economic Growth: Provides higher income for farmers and contributes to national exports.
  • Job Creation: Encourages agro-industries, cold storage, and processing units.
  • Food Security: Ensures a steady supply of grains, fruits, and vegetables for the market.

Disadvantages / Concerns

  • Ecological Issues: Excessive use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides leads to soil degradation, water pollution, and biodiversity loss.
  • Farmer Vulnerability: Farmers become dependent on market fluctuations, seed companies, and external inputs, which can increase financial risk.
  • Water Overuse: Intensive irrigation often causes groundwater depletion, especially in Punjab and Haryana.
  • Monocropping Risks: Growing only one type of crop (monoculture) makes fields vulnerable to pests, diseases, and climate change.

Recent Trends

  • Precision Farming: Use of AI, IoT, and data analytics to optimize inputs and maximize yields.
  • Organic Commercial Farming: Rising global demand for organic fruits, vegetables, and spices.
  • Export Orientation: Horticulture, floriculture, and aquaculture gaining momentum in global trade.
  • Government Support: Schemes like PM-Kisan, e-NAM (National Agriculture Market), MSP procurement, and subsidies for irrigation & fertilizers.
news.n17_snippet: Dry land farming is practiced in regions with less than 75 cm of annual rainfall and limited irrigation.
news.n17_article:
Dry Land Farming

Definition:

Dry land farming is practiced in regions receiving less than 75 cm of rainfall annually, where irrigation facilities are either absent or very limited.

Crops Grown:

  • Drought-tolerant cereals such as millets (ragi, bajra), sorghum (jowar).
  • Pulses like gram and pigeon pea (tur/arhar).
  • Oilseeds such as groundnut and sunflower.

Techniques Used:

  • Water harvesting to store rainwater.
  • Soil conservation methods like mulching, bunding, contour ploughing, and planting shelterbelts.
  • Use of drought-resistant crop varieties.

Regions in India:

Deccan Plateau, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Telangana, and parts of Karnataka & Maharashtra.

Advantages:

  • Best suited for arid and semi-arid regions.
  • Promotes the use of traditional drought-resistant crops like millets, which are highly nutritious.

Challenges:

  • Erratic and scarce rainfall reduces yields.
  • High risk of crop failure.
  • Poor soil fertility and desertification risk.
news.n18_snippet: Shifting cultivation (Jhum) is a traditional method where forest land is cleared and cultivated for a few years.
news.n18_article:
Shifting Cultivation (Jhum)

Definition:

Shifting cultivation, locally known as Jhum, is a traditional method where forest land is cleared, vegetation is burned, and crops are grown for a few years until the soil loses fertility. Farmers then abandon the land and move to a new patch.

Crops Grown:

Maize, upland rice, millets, pulses, ginger, chillies, and root crops.

Process:

  • Forest patch cleared and trees burned.
  • Ash acts as a temporary fertilizer.
  • Crops cultivated for 2–3 years.
  • Land is left fallow for natural rejuvenation.

Regions in India:

Common in North-Eastern states (Nagaland, Mizoram, Meghalaya, Arunachal Pradesh, Manipur, Tripura) and tribal belts of Odisha, Chhattisgarh, and Jharkhand.

Advantages:

  • Low-cost farming method.
  • Preserves some traditional and indigenous farming knowledge.

Challenges:

  • Leads to deforestation, soil erosion, and biodiversity loss.
  • Declining fallow period due to population pressure has reduced soil recovery.
  • Considered unsustainable in the long run.
news.n19_snippet: Capitalist farming is a profit-oriented commercial system for mass production of cash crops.
news.n19_article:
Capitalist Farming

Definition:

Capitalist farming is a profit-oriented commercial system, where large areas are used for the mass production of cash crops using modern technology and inputs.

Crops Grown:

Cotton, sugarcane, oilseeds, wheat, rice, maize.

Features:

  • Intensive use of HYV seeds, chemical fertilizers, pesticides, and advanced irrigation systems.
  • Heavy mechanization with tractors, harvesters, and drones.
  • Highly dependent on market demand and global trade.

Regions in India:

Large-scale farms are found in Punjab, Haryana, Maharashtra, Gujarat, and Andhra Pradesh.

Advantages:

  • Ensures high productivity and income.
  • Encourages industrial growth (textiles, sugar industry, edible oils).
  • Creates employment in agri-business and allied sectors.

Challenges:

  • Soil degradation and water depletion due to overuse of chemicals and irrigation.
  • Farmers become dependent on external inputs like seeds and fertilizers.
  • Market fluctuations expose farmers to financial risks.
news.n20_snippet: Mixed farming combines crop cultivation with livestock rearing for income stability and resource utilization.
news.n20_article:
Mixed Farming

Definition:

Mixed farming combines crop cultivation with livestock rearing. It is an integrated and sustainable system that improves income stability and resource utilization.

Crops & Livestock:

  • Crops: Rice, wheat, maize, vegetables, fruits.
  • Livestock: Cattle, buffaloes, goats, poultry, and sheep.

Features:

  • Livestock provides milk, eggs, and manure.
  • Crop residues feed animals.
  • Manure improves soil fertility → reducing dependence on chemical fertilizers.

Regions in India:

Widely practiced in Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu.

Advantages:

  • Ensures diversified income (from both crops and animals).
  • Promotes nutrient recycling and soil health.
  • Increases resilience to crop failure.

Challenges:

  • Requires better management of both crops and animals.
  • Limited adoption of modern techniques in small farms.
news.n21_snippet: Mediterranean farming is practiced in regions with hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters.
news.n21_article:
Mediterranean Farming

Definition:

Mediterranean farming is practiced in regions with hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters. In India, this type of farming is limited but emerging in selected areas.

Crops Grown:

Olives, grapes, figs, citrus fruits, and almonds. Recently, olive farming has been promoted in parts of India.

Regions in India:

Himachal Pradesh, Rajasthan (Barmer, Jalore), Jammu & Kashmir.

Advantages:

  • Suitable for water-scarce regions, as crops like olives require less water.
  • Generates high-value products like olive oil and wine grapes.
  • Creates export opportunities and local employment.

Challenges:

  • Not widely practiced in India due to climate limitations.
  • Requires specialized knowledge and infrastructure.
  • High initial investment for orchards and processing units.
news.n22_title: Policies Supporting Seed Technology in India
news.n22_snippet: An overview of the key acts and regulations that support the development and use of seed technology in India.
news.n22_article:
Policies and Regulations that Support Seed Technology in India

Protection of Plant Varieties & Farmers Rights Act (PPV&FR Act), 2001:

  • This act provides intellectual property rights protection to plant breeders and farmers for their varieties and innovations.
  • It also encourages the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources.

Seeds Act, 1966 and Seeds Rules, 1968:

  • These acts and rules regulate the quality control and certification of seeds in India.
  • They also prescribe the standards and procedures for seed testing, labeling, and marketing.

Fertiliser (Inorganic, Organic or Mixed) (Control) Amendment Order, 2021:

  • This order amends the Fertiliser (Inorganic, Organic or Mixed) (Control Order, 1985 to include bio-stimulants as a category of fertilizers.
  • Bio-stimulants are substances or microorganisms that enhance plant growth and development.
  • This order will facilitate the registration and use of bio-stimulants in India.
news.n23_title: Why is Seed Technology Important for Indian Agriculture?
news.n23_snippet: Seed technology increases productivity, enhances input efficiency, and builds crop resilience against climate change.
news.n23_article:
Why is Seed Technology Important for Indian Agriculture?

Higher Productivity:

  • Seed technology can increase the yield potential of crops by developing improved varieties that have desirable traits, such as high grain or fruit quality, resistance to pests and diseases, tolerance to drought or salinity, etc.
  • Seed technology can also improve the germination rate, seedling vigour, and plant establishment of seeds by using priming or physiological advancement protocols.

Higher Input Use Efficiency:

  • Seed technology can reduce the amount and cost of inputs such as fertilizers, pesticides, and water by using film coating, pelleting, or seed treatments that can deliver these inputs directly to the seeds or plants in optimal doses.
  • Seed technology can also enhance the nutrient uptake and utilization of plants by using bio-stimulants and nutrients that can stimulate plant growth and metabolism.

Higher Resilience:

  • Seed technology can improve the adaptability and stability of crops under changing and unpredictable climatic conditions by using genetic manipulation, speed breeding, gene-editing-tools, or AI-responsive sensors or substances that can modulate plant responses to external stimuli.
  • Seed technology can also improve the diversity and health of crops by using biologicals or microbial inoculum that can enhance plant immunity and soil fertility.
news.n24_title: Examples of Seed Technologies in India
news.n24_snippet: Exploring advancements in millet, cotton, and vegetable seeds that are transforming Indian agriculture.
news.n24_article:
What are Some Examples of Seed Technologies in Use or Development in India?

Millet Seeds:

  • Millets are nutrient-rich, hardy and short-cycle crops that are well-suited for sustainable agriculture.
  • India is the global leader in millet production and has the potential to capture the global seed market by producing quality-assured seeds of improved varieties of millets, especially minor millets.
  • India has developed several high-yielding and climate-resilient varieties of millets using conventional breeding and molecular techniques.
  • India has also introduced priming and film coating technologies for millet seeds to improve their germination, emergence, uniformity, and protection.

Cotton Seeds:

  • Cotton is one of the most important cash crops in India and a major source of income for millions of farmers.
  • India has achieved remarkable success in cotton production by introducing Bt cotton hybrids in 2002.
  • Bt cotton is a transgenic crop that expresses a gene from a soil bacterium called Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) that produces a protein that kills certain insect pests.
  • Bt cotton has increased cotton yield by reducing pest damage and pesticide use.
  • India has also developed several new varieties of cotton using molecular breeding and gene-editing-tools that have improved traits such as fibre quality, drought tolerance, herbicide resistance, etc.

Vegetable Seeds:

  • India has a diverse range of vegetable crops that require different types of seeds.
  • India has developed many improved varieties and hybrids of vegetables using conventional breeding and biotechnology methods.
  • India has also introduced various seed enhancement technologies for vegetable seeds such as film coating, pelleting, priming, bio-stimulants, nutrients, biologicals, etc., to improve their quality and performance.

govtSchemes.title: Government Schemes for Farmers
govtSchemes.subtitle: Explore beneficial programs and support from the government.

pmkisan.name: Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi
pmkisan.shortDescription: Provides income support to all landholding farmers' families to supplement their financial needs for agriculture and domestic needs.

pmfby.name: Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana
pmfby.shortDescription: Provides insurance coverage and financial support to farmers in the event of crop failure due to natural calamities, pests, and diseases.

enam.name: E-NAM (National Agriculture Market)
enam.shortDescription: eNAM (National Agriculture Market) is a pan-India electronic trading portal that networks the existing APMC (Agriculture Produce Marketing Committee) mandis to create a unified national market for agricultural commodities.

pmkmy.name: Pradhan Mantri Kisan Maandhan Yojana
pmkmy.shortDescription: A voluntary and contributory pension scheme for small and marginal farmers in India to ensure financial security in their old age.

kcc.name: Kisan Credit Card
kcc.shortDescription: Provides adequate and timely credit to farmers for their agricultural operations at a subsidized interest rate.

cmkky.name: Chief Minister Kisan Kalyan Yojana
cmkky.shortDescription: An initiative by the Government of Madhya Pradesh to provide financial assistance to farmers.

shc.name: RKVY Soil Health and Fertility - Soil Health Card
shc.shortDescription: Provides farmers with a report on their soil's health and customized nutrient recommendations.

smam.name: Sub-mission On Agriculture Mechanization (SMAM)
smam.shortDescription: Promotes farm mechanization by providing subsidies on agricultural machinery to increase farm power availability.

welfareOfFishermen.name: National Scheme Of Welfare Of Fishermen
welfareOfFishermen.shortDescription: Provides financial assistance to fishermen for house construction, community halls, and other basic amenities.

pmgsy.name: Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana
pmgsy.shortDescription: Aims to provide all-weather road connectivity to eligible unconnected habitations in rural areas.

organicManure.name: Organic Manure Scheme
organicManure.shortDescription: Provides hands-on training on the production of organic compost for sustainable agriculture.

coffeeDev.name: Coffee Development Programme in North Eastern Region
coffeeDev.shortDescription: Aims to improve coffee quality by establishing infrastructure and obtaining certification.

aiFarmer.title: AI किसान सहायक
aiFarmer.subtitle: तुमचा वैयक्तिक कृषी तज्ञ, 24/7 उपलब्ध.
aiFarmer.locationPrompt: हवामान-जागरूक सल्ला देण्यासाठी, कृपया तुमचे स्थान प्रविष्ट करा (उदा., 'दिल्ली, भारत'):

clearChatDialog.title: तुम्ही पूर्णपणे खात्री आहात का?
clearChatDialog.description: ही क्रिया पूर्ववत केली जाऊ शकत नाही. हे तुमच्या सध्याच्या चॅट इतिहासाला कायमचे हटवेल.

idle.example: उदा., "वालुकामय जमिनीसाठी सर्वोत्तम सिंचन पद्धती कोणत्या आहेत?"

loadingMessages.m1: 🌱 AI खताने तुमचे उत्तर वाढवत आहे... कृपया प्रतीक्षा करा.
loadingMessages.m2: 🔍 डेटाच्या मातीचे स्कॅनिंग करत आहे... थोडा वेळ थांबा.
loadingMessages.m3: 💡 ढगातून ज्ञानाची कापणी करत आहे... फक्त एक सेकंद.
loadingMessages.m4: 📡 कृषी उपग्रहांशी कनेक्ट होत आहे... कृपया प्रतीक्षा करा.
loadingMessages.m5: 🌱 ज्ञानाची बीजे पेरत आहे... तुमचे उत्तर उगवत आहे, थोडा वेळ थांबा.
loadingMessages.m6: 🐄 ताज्या उत्तरांसाठी दूध काढत आहे... जवळजवळ झाले, थांबा.
loadingMessages.m7: 📊 धान्य वाढण्यापूर्वी मोजत आहे... कृपया प्रतीक्षा करा.
loadingMessages.m8: 🐓 कोंबड्यांकडून सल्ला विचारत आहे... त्या लवकरच प्रतिसाद देतील, एक क्षण थांबा.
loadingMessages.m9: 🐄 कीबोर्डवरून गाईंना हाकलत आहे... फक्त एक सेकंद, तुमचे उत्तर येत आहे.
loadingMessages.m10: 🌾 योग्य शब्दांची कापणी करत आहे... कृपया प्रतीक्षा करा.

saveError.title: चॅट इतिहास जतन करू शकलो नाही
saveError.description: चॅट इतिहास खूप मोठा आहे आणि तो जतन केला जाऊ शकत नाही.

adviceError.title: त्रुटी
adviceError.description: सल्ला मिळविण्यात अयशस्वी. कृपया पुन्हा प्रयत्न करा.

chatCleared.title: चॅट साफ केले
chatCleared.description: तुमचा चॅट इतिहास साफ केला गेला आहे.

voiceNotSupported.title: व्हॉइस समर्थित नाही
voiceNotSupported.description: तुमचा ब्राउझर व्हॉइस ओळखण्यास समर्थन देत नाही.

diseaseClassification.title: पीक रोग वर्गीकरण
diseaseClassification.subtitle: रोगांचे लवकर निदान करण्यासाठी पीकाच्या पाल्याचे चित्र अपलोड करा.

uploadCard.title: पीकाचे चित्र अपलोड करा
uploadCard.description: उत्तम परिणामांसाठी, एकाच पाल्याचे स्पष्ट, जवळून घेतलेले चित्र वापरा.

status.idle: निदान मिळवण्यासाठी एक चित्र अपलोड करा

noFile.title: कोणतीही फाइल निवडलेली नाही
noFile.description: कृपया पीकाच्या पाल्याचे चित्र अपलोड करा.

failure.title: वर्गीकरण अयशस्वी
failure.description: चित्र विश्लेषण करू शकलो नाही. कृपया दुसरे चित्र वापरून प्रयत्न करा.

animalClassification.title: प्राणी वर्गीकरण
animalClassification.subtitle: पाळीव प्राणी किंवा वन्यजीवांसाठी, एका चित्रातून प्राण्यांच्या प्रजाती ओळखा.

uploadCard.title: प्राण्याचे चित्र अपलोड करा
uploadCard.description: तुम्ही ओळखू इच्छित असलेल्या प्राण्याचे स्पष्ट चित्र द्या.

status.idle: प्राणी ओळखण्यासाठी एक चित्र अपलोड करा

toast.noFileDescription: कृपया एका प्राण्याचे चित्र अपलोड करा.
toast.failureDescription: चित्र विश्लेषण करू शकलो नाही. कृपया दुसरे चित्र वापरून प्रयत्न करा.

cropYield.title: पीक उत्पन्न अंदाज
cropYield.subtitle: तुमच्या पिकाचा अंदाज घेण्यासाठी आणि तुमची रणनीती ऑप्टिमाइझ करण्यासाठी AI चा लाभ घ्या.

additionalNotes.placeholder: अतिरिक्त नोंदी (उदा., इतर फवारण्या वापरल्या, कीटकांच्या समस्या)

status.loading: तुमचा स्मार्ट सहाय्यक शेतातून फिरत आहे...
status.idle: AI तुमचे पीक मोजण्यासाठी तयार आहे — फक्त अंदाज लावा वर क्लिक करा.

toast.errorDescription: अंदाज मिळविण्यात अयशस्वी. कृपया पुन्हा प्रयत्न करा.

cropYield.mlModelInfo: हा फॉर्म काम करत नसल्यास ML मॉडेलवर क्लिक करा आणि वापरा

locationDialog.title: तुमचे स्थान प्रविष्ट करा
locationDialog.description: तुम्हाला चांगले परिणाम हवे असल्यास, आजच्या हवामान डेटा मिळवण्यासाठी तुमचे स्थान प्रविष्ट करा.
locationDialog.label: स्थान

login.leftPanelDescription: आमच्याशी कनेक्ट राहण्यासाठी कृपया तुमच्या वैयक्तिक माहितीसह लॉगिन करा
login.rightPanelDescription: तुमचे वैयक्तिक तपशील प्रविष्ट करा आणि आमच्यासोबत प्रवास सुरू करा

error.title: प्रमाणीकरण त्रुटी
error.invalidCredentials: तुम्ही प्रविष्ट केलेला ईमेल किंवा पासवर्ड चुकीचा आहे. कृपया पुन्हा प्रयत्न करा.
error.signupFailed: वापरकर्त्याला साइन अप करू शकलो नाही. हा ईमेल आधीच वापरात असू शकतो.
error.profileCreation: वापरकर्ता प्रोफाइल तयार करण्यात अयशस्वी. कृपया समर्थनाशी संपर्क साधा.

judgeInfo.title: SIH न्यायाधीश आणि परीक्षकांसाठी
judgeInfo.description: वैयक्तिकृत डॅशबोर्ड दृश्ये एक्सप्लोर करण्यासाठी ही डमी क्रेडेन्शियल वापरा.

dashboard.subtitle: तुमच्या शेतासाठी हवामान अंदाज, बाजार विश्लेषण आणि शिफारस केलेल्या योजनांसह एक वैयक्तिकृत हब.

yieldHistory.title: उत्पन्न अंदाज इतिहास
yieldHistory.description: आम्हाला सुधारण्यास मदत करण्यासाठी तुमच्या वास्तविक कापणीच्या तुलनेत AI अंदाजांचा मागोवा घ्या.

chatHistory.title: अलीकडील AI चॅट्स
chatHistory.description: AI शेतकरी सहाय्यकासोबतच्या तुमच्या ताज्या संभाषणांचे पटकन पुनरावलोकन करा.

schemes.title: तुमच्यासाठी शिफारस केलेल्या योजना
schemes.description: तुमच्या प्रोफाइलवर आधारित, या सरकारी योजना फायदेशीर असू शकतात.

weather.title: हवामान दृष्टिकोन आणि सूचना
weather.description: तुमच्या स्थानासाठी सध्याची परिस्थिती आणि कार्यवाही करण्यायोग्य सल्ला: {location}.
weather.error: हवामान डेटा लोड करू शकलो नाही. कृपया नंतर पुन्हा प्रयत्न करा.
weather.retryButton: पुन्हा प्रयत्न करण्यासाठी स्थान प्रविष्ट करा

market.title: {crop} साठी बाजारभाव विश्लेषण
market.description: ऐतिहासिक किमतींचा मागोवा घ्या आणि AI-चालित अंदाज मिळवा.
market.errorDescription: बाजार डेटा लोड करू शकलो नाही. कृपया नंतर पुन्हा प्रयत्न करा.
market.initial_prompt: Get a real-time AI analysis of the market for your primary crop.

loading.schemes: शिफारस केलेल्या योजना लोड होत आहेत...

animalComparison.title: पशु आणि म्हैस जातीची तुलना
animalComparison.subtitle: त्यांच्या वैशिष्ट्यांची तुलना करण्यासाठी दोन जातींपर्यंत निवडा.

findVeterinarian.title: पशुवैद्य शोधा
findVeterinarian.subtitle: भारतातील जिल्हा पशुसंवर्धन अधिकाऱ्यांसाठी संपर्क माहिती. तुमचे राज्य निवडा.
findVeterinarian.stateSubtitle: {stateName} मधील पशुवैद्यकीय दवाखाने आणि रुग्णालयांसाठी संपर्क माहिती शोधा.
findVeterinarian.stateDataMissing: {stateName} साठी डेटा अद्याप उपलब्ध नाही. कृपया नंतर पुन्हा तपासा.
findVeterinarian.noClinicsFound: तुमच्या शोधाशी जुळणारे कोणतेही दवाखाने सापडले नाहीत.
findVeterinarian.noClinicsListed: या राज्यासाठी अद्याप कोणतेही दवाखाने सूचीबद्ध नाहीत.

areaInfo.title: त्वरित माहिती केंद्र
areaInfo.description: तुमच्या बोटांच्या टोकावर आवश्यक कृषी डेटा.
